Knowledge Sharing System: Access to be sent individually    

The new Knowledge Sharing System (KSS) presented at the last ALNF in Istanbul is a password-protected website for GCLN Focal Points. It will allow Local Networks to easily share information regarding activities and governance-related issues. It will also facilitate the production of the annual activity report at the end of each year.

In the coming days, each GCLN Focal Point will be provided with an individual user account and a guidance note outlining how to access and update the Knowledge Sharing System. GCLNs are kindly asked to check the accuracy of the information currently contained within the system and to upload any/all missing information. Moving forward, Local Networks are asked to keep the KSS regularly updated with new events and activities as this will allow for the optimal level of sharing and learning among Networks.

Model for funding of GCLN and Foundation for the Global Compact    

The GCLN Germany recently established, under German law, a foundation to collect contributions for the GCLN from German Global Compact participants. The “Foundation GCLN Germany” is also a mechanism through which German participants can contribute to the US-based “Foundation for the Global Compact”. Depending on your country’s tax law, this model could serve as an example for your Global Compact Local Network.

In the case of the “Foundation GCLN Germany”, contributors can specify that a certain amount of the contribution is to be forwarded to the US-based “Foundation for the Global Compact”. The “Foundation GCLN Germany” then transfers the amount specified to the US-based “Foundation for the Global Compact” while the entire amount is tax-deductible under German tax law.

Proper use of UN Global Compact logos by GCLNs    

We would once again like to draw your attention to the rules and regulations governing the use of the logo.

Specifically, we would like to highlight the following:

    1) Only those Networks that have entered into an MOU with the GCO are permitted to use the “GCLN logo”.
    2) GCLNs are only authorized to use the “GCLN logo” in conjunction with the networks activities and not the “UN” or “GC” logos.
    3) Network Representatives and Focal Points have to make reference to the “Network” and not the Global Compact in general in email signatures, business cards etc. It should be clearly understood that they represent the group of participants from their respective country and not the Global Compact Office.

HUMAN RIGHTS

Human rights webinar for Local Network focal points     

For many Local Networks, human rights and business can be a difficult topic to work on. How to approach the topic? What activities to undertake? Sometimes even saying the words "human rights" can be challenging. If Local Network focal points would find it helpful, the Global Compact Office would be pleased to host a webinar (a combination of a telephone conference and weblink that is free of charge for Local Networks) to explore this topic in more detail and featuring examples from Local Networks around the world how they have been approaching the topic and what activities they have been undertaking. The webinar would also include a discussion period to enable Local Networks to raise challenges and questions. The webinar would be closed and confidential to enable all to speak freely. Please contact Ursula Wynhoven by 30 September if you would be interested to participate either as a participant or as a presenter to share your Network's experience. We will then follow up to suggest some dates.

AFRICA

New report on CSR in sub-Sahara Africa launched    

A report “Corporate Social Responsibility in sub-Saharan Africa – A survey on promoting and hindering factors” has recently been published by the Deutsche Gesellschaft fuer Technische Zusammenarbeit GTZ with funding by the British High Commission South Africa. The publication, which is available for download here, is based on 85 interviews with companies in six African countries (South Africa, Malawi, Mozambique, Ghana, Kenya and Namibia). It contributes to a better understanding of companies’ motivation and potential to incorporate CSR into their regular business in sub-Sahara Africa.    

LATIN AMERICA

New ILO guide: Combating forced labor for managers and companies     

El nuevo manual de la Oficina Internacional del Trabajo (OIT) “Lucha contra el trabajo forzoso: Un manual para los empleadores y las empresas” proporciona orientación detallada para los empleadores y las empresas para abordar el trabajo forzoso y la trata de seres humanos. El manual proporciona orientación sobre la identificación de lo que es y no es el trabajo forzoso, medidas preventivas y correctivas, y el desarrollo de buenas prácticas para abordar la cuestión. Entre las herramientas proporcionadas por el manual hay un conjunto de principios rectores para combatir el trabajo forzoso, una lista de control para evaluar el cumplimiento, y una guía y una serie de consejos prácticos para la adopción de medidas. Copias del manual en español se puede pedir de la OIT.

Por mas informacion, contactense: Philip Hunter, OIT Programa de Acción Especial para Combatir el Trabajo Forzoso, hunterp@ilo.org
